results.title: Ablutions
results.brief_description: Ablutions is an interactive journey where the user controls the fate of a character in a world that consumes technology. Through exploring the narrative the user partakes in the experience of cleansing the self from everyday technology and its commodities; questioning the nature of our identity. By doing this, freedom is redefined. Once cleansed, the character recovers the lost items, discovering their meaning and importance.

results.title: Testimony: a story machine
results.brief_description:
“Testimony: A Story Machine” is an interactive comic strip. It is a story to be played with. The user may click where s/he pleases, causing images to be replaced, or characters to animate and change position. By changing one image in a sequence of (say) four frames, the story implied by the sequence of four is altered, even when the other three frames remain static. The ideas for the project came from my previous experiments with cut-up collages of text and cut-up collages of comics, and also my interest in film and shot sequence and comics and frame sequence.
While the user plays with the interactive, sometimes the story will change, sometimes it will advance to a new setting. The library of images, animation, text and sound is composed of broadly similar narrative themes, but it is the sequence which determines the story. There is no end. There are no rules for interpreting the story. The user cannot do anything wrong and how the user interprets what they find is up to them. It is a work of non-linear fiction. As author, I provide the ingredients, the computer provides the sequencing and the reader provides the meaning or interpretation.

results.title: Chromos
results.brief_description: Chromos is a computer-generated work which uses computational processes called ‘cellular automata’ to produce patterns which change over time. Cellular automata were conceived by Stanislaw Ulam and John von Neumann in the 1940s, and popularised by John Conway’s Game of Life in the late 1960s. Each cell - like the individual tiles that make up chromos - is a discrete system that follows its own simple rules. These rules govern the transitions of the tiles over time. Although both the tiles and the rules are simple, the overall behaviour of the system is complex and unpredictable. Chromos, like any beautiful design, invites contemplation, so rather than try to identify the mathematical rules at play, most viewers will happily lose themselves in the entrancing visual maze. The work engages aspects of behavioural and cognitive theories and theories of creativity. The human brain has evolved to seek meaning and so many viewers of cellular automata believe they are witnessing a much higher degree of intelligence and lifelike-ness than is implicit in the system itself. Conversely these systems also enable us to perceive that many aspects of human intelligence and creativity are perhaps nothing more than the outcome of simple but unpredictable behavioural processes.

results.title: Departure
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
In Departure, Ian Andrews has used mostly analogue techniques to evoke the decaying process that occurs in a film or photographic image over time, but in doing so, he has created an altogether different visual landscape in which different layers of image contest and compete against each other.
A small strip of found film footage of a man “departing” loops endlessly back and forth, and as it does so, the repeated actions of the man seem to physically alter the layers, the skin of film and image through which we watch this action take place. The figure is marking out the landscape by traversing it, by exiting the frame and leaving a ghostly trace of his presence - but it is the surface of the visual form itself that is left marked.

results.title: Dreams of return
results.creator_credit: Julie Shiels, Michael Buckley, Timorese Association of Victoria and North Richmond Community Health Centre
results.brief_description: This CDROM has been funded by the Australian Film Commission and is primarily about the experiences of Timorese refugees living in Australia. The work is a contemporary look at identity, resistance and the dream of return to East Timor. The CDROM is shaped around the performance and cultural work (including dance, drumming and storytelling) developed by members of the East Timorese community who are based at the North Richmond community health centre. The work in this CDROM was developed in conjunction with the Timorese association of Victoria.
